defs.docs:
The purpose of this library is to provide an OpenGL [`Context`] on as many
 platforms as possible.

attributes.value: ! The purpose of this library is to provide an OpenGL [`Context`] on as many
! A [`WindowedContext<T>`] is composed of a [`Window`] and an OpenGL
! Due to some operating-system-specific quirks, glutin prefers control over
! the order of creation of the [`Context`] and [`Window`]. Here is an example
! You can, of course, create a [`RawContext<T>`] separately from an existing
! window, however that may result in an suboptimal configuration of the window
! on some platforms. In that case use the unsafe platform-specific
! You can also produce headless [`Context`]s via the

cfg(any
      (target_os = "linux", target_os = "ios", target_os = "windows",
       target_os = "macos", target_os = "android", target_os = "dragonfly",
       target_os = "freebsd", target_os = "netbsd", target_os = "openbsd",
       target_os = "emscripten",))

attributes.value: / When on linux, prefer [`build_surfaceless`]. If both
/ [`build_surfaceless`] and `build_headless` fail, try using a hidden
/ window, or [`build_osmesa`]. Please note that if you choose to use a
/ hidden window, you must still handle the events it generates on the
/ Errors can occur in two scenarios:
/  - If the window could not be created (via permission denied,
/  incompatible system, out of memory, etc.). This should be very rare.
/  - If the OpenGL [`Context`] could not be created. This generally
/  because the underlying platform doesn't support a requested feature.

Split the [`Window`] apart from the OpenGL [`Context`]. Should only be

/   - The OpenGL [`Context`] must be dropped before the [`Window`].

defs.name: swap_buffers
defs.docs: Swaps the buffers in case of double or triple buffering.

attributes.value: / Swaps the buffers in case of double or triple buffering.
/ You should call this function every time you have finished rendering, or
/ the image may not be displayed on the screen.
/ **Warning**: if you enabled vsync, this function will block until the
/ next time the screen is refreshed. However drivers can choose to
/ override your vsync settings, which means that you can't know in
/ advance whether `swap_buffers` will block or not.

defs.name: get_pixel_format
defs.docs: Returns the pixel format of the main framebuffer of the context.

attributes.value: / Returns the pixel format of the main framebuffer of the context.

defs.name: resize
defs.docs: Resize the context.

attributes.value: / Some platforms (macOS, Wayland) require being manually updated when
/ their window or surface is resized.
/ The easiest way of doing this is to take every [`Resized`] window event
/ that is received with a [`LogicalSize`] and convert it to a
/ [`PhysicalSize`] and pass it into this function.

defs.name: context
defs.docs: Borrow the inner GL [`Context`].

defs.name: make_current
defs.docs:
Sets this context as the current context. The previously current context
 (if any) is no longer current.

attributes.value: / Sets this context as the current context. The previously current context
/ A failed call to `make_current` might make this, or no context
/ current. It could also keep the previous context current. What happens
/ To attempt to recover and get back into a know state, either:
/  * attempt to use [`is_current`] to find the new current context; or
/ In OpenGl, only a single context can be current in a thread at a time.
/ Making a new context current will make the old one not current.
/ Contexts can only be sent to different threads if they are not current.
/ If you call `make_current` on some context, you should call
/ [`treat_as_not_current`] as soon as possible on the previously current
/ If you wish to move a currently current context to a different thread,
/ you should do one of two options:
/  * Call `make_current` on an other context, then call
/ If you are aware of what context you intend to make current next, it is
/ preferable for performance reasons to call `make_current` on that
/ If you are not aware of what context you intend to make current next,
/ consider waiting until you do. If you need this context not current
/ immediately (e.g. to transfer it to an other thread), then call
/ Please avoid calling [`make_not_current`] on one context only to call
/ `make_current` on an other context before and/or after. This hurts
/  * Check if this context is current; then
/  * If it is, change the current context from this context to none; then
/  * Change the current context from none to the new context.
/ Instead prefer the method we mentioned above with `make_current` and

defs.name: make_not_current

 context is not current however, this function does nothing.

defs.name: treat_as_not_current
defs.docs:
Treats this context as not current, even if it is current. We do no
 checks to confirm that this is actually case.

/ If unsure whether or not this context is current, please use
/ [`make_not_current`] which will do nothing if this context is not

/ Please see [`make_current`] for the prefered method of handling context

Not everything is checked. Your application can crash if you do

defs.name: NoError
defs.docs:
The driver doesn't check anything. This option is very dangerous.
 Please know what you're doing before using it. See the
 `GL_KHR_no_error` extension.

attributes.value: / The driver doesn't check anything. This option is very dangerous.
/ Please know what you're doing before using it. See the
/ Since this option is purely an optimization, no error will be returned

defs.name: RobustNoResetNotification
defs.docs:
Everything is checked to avoid any crash. The driver will attempt to
 avoid any problem, but if a problem occurs the behavior is
 implementation-defined. You are just guaranteed not to get a crash.

attributes.value: / Everything is checked to avoid any crash. The driver will attempt to
/ avoid any problem, but if a problem occurs the behavior is
/ implementation-defined. You are just guaranteed not to get a crash.

defs.name: TryRobustNoResetNotification
defs.docs:
Same as [`RobustNoResetNotification`] but the context creation doesn't
 fail if it's not supported.

attributes.value: / Same as [`RobustNoResetNotification`] but the context creation doesn't

defs.name: RobustLoseContextOnReset
defs.docs:
Everything is checked to avoid any crash. If a problem occurs, the
 context will enter a "context lost" state. It must then be
 recreated. For the moment, glutin doesn't provide a way to recreate
 a context with the same window :-/

attributes.value: / Everything is checked to avoid any crash. If a problem occurs, the
/ context will enter a "context lost" state. It must then be

defs.name: vsync
defs.docs:
Whether to use vsync. If vsync is enabled, calling `swap_buffers` will
 block until the screen refreshes. This is typically used to prevent
 screen tearing.

defs.name: map_sharing
defs.docs: Turns the `sharing` parameter into another type by calling a closure.
